results.title: In harbour
results.creator_credit: Joan Boundy, Eric Thompson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Shows the work of the many people who are engaged in working on Sydney Harbour - the fishermen who gain their livelihood from its waters, those who maintain its laws and ensure its cleanliness, those who maintain its equipment and preserve its many miles of wharves and those who dredge its bed and attend to its buoys. They keep the harbour for the ships from many lands to use, but themselves never go “outside”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joan Boundy, Eric Thompson and Australian National Film Board

They keep the harbour for the ships from many lands to use, but themselves never go “outside”.

results.title: In Grave danger of falling food/barefoot economist
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Visionaries”.
In Grave Danger of Falling Food - Bill Mollison believes that the most destructive force on the planet is modern agriculture. It destroys our soils, poisons our water and produces toxic food. Instead, he has designed Permaculture, a system that uses the engineering principles of nature itself. He combines hundreds of plants and animals into a fertile self-regulating ecosystem. “Barefoot Economist” - Manfred Max-Neef is a Chilean economist trying to address the problems of Latin America. He thinks the worst solutions are those imposed from the top by financial planners, and the best are those worked out on the ground by local communities.

results.title: In grave danger of falling food
results.creator_credit: Tony Gailey, Julian Russell and 220 Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Visionaries”.
Bill Mollison believes that the single most destructive force on the planet is modern agriculture. It is destroying our soils, poisoning our water and producing toxic food. Instead, he has proposed a system of agriculture - permaculture - that uses the principles of Nature itself. He combines hundreds of species, plant and animal, into a fertile, self-regulating ecosystem. These permaculture systems can be applied to the city as well as the country, and can work in any climate.

He combines hundreds of species, plant and animal, into a fertile, self-regulating ecosystem. These permaculture systems can be applied to the city as well as the country, and can work in any climate.

results.title: In good heart
results.creator_credit: Henry Cooper and Campbell Harper Films
results.brief_description: A description of the farming year in Scotland as seen in the lives of four farmers in the Border country, Ayrshire, the Highlands and Angus, and a reminder of the help received by farmers from various research institutes in their efforts to improve livestock and keep the land in the best possible condition.

results.title: In good company
results.brief_description: A recruiting film made to encourage young men to join the Army as officers. Shows the Officers Training School at Portsea in Victoria, the Royal Military College at Duntroon in Canberra and gives an insight into the lifestyle and career opportunities offered by the Army to any young man who wishes both to further his education at a tertiary level as well as seek a challenging and rewarding career as an officer in the Australian Army.

results.title: In good company
results.creator_credit: Syd Wood, Frank Killian and Movietonenews
results.brief_description: Role and training in Australian Citizen Military Forces of part-time soldiers important in Australia’s defence; attendance at weekly parades, weekend bivouacs and annual camps where modern weapons, mock-up battles are used to provide realistic battle and trade experience. Army medical nurses, Women’s Royal Australian Army Corps, and Commandos learn bandaging, marching and boat-handling respectively as they train. Commentator: Kevin Golsby.

results.title: In God's hands
results.creator_credit: Zalman King, Tom Stern and Tri-Star Pictures
results.brief_description: In God’s Hands follows three friends and surfers around the world in their quest for the perfect wave. They travel to Madagascar, Mexico, Bali and Hawaii where their training is put to the test when faced with 40 foot waves travelling at 35 miles per hour. Includes stunning water photography by Sonny Miller. Cast includes: Patrick Shane Dorian, Matt George, Matty Liu and Shaun Tomson.

results.title: In God's command
results.creator_credit: Garth Pritchard, Graydon McCrea, Jerry Krepakevich and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Throughout the history of war there has been the silent presence of the army chaplain, a comforting person in the midst of atrocities, offering spiritual support and material comfort. ‘In God’s command’ offers an intimate portrait of one such chaplain, Captain Mark Sargent, army officer, Roman Catholic priest and chaplain to the soldiers of the First Battalion; Princess Patricia’s Canadian light infantry, stationed in the former Yugoslavia. The viewer follows Sargent as he ministers soldiers and civilians, arranging Mass, celebrating a baptism, and performs other priestly duties under the most trying conditions with conviction, compassion and humor. Narrated by military historian Gywnne Dyer.

results.title: In flux
results.creator_credit: Ryan Linfors, Legacy and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: When Ryan joined Legacy, he was six years old and fatherless. Legacy taught him about acceptance and gave him three close friends. He tells of his relationship with Bec, Bear and Brad and how they have been there for him and have recently helped him in his decision to become a Legacy leader.

results.title: In fear of every dawn [Magnetic soundtrack]
results.brief_description: Western propaganda presenting life on the Eastern side of the ‘Berlin Wall’. Filmed from the Western side of the border, the film records activities on the Eastern side and provides an anti-communist interpretation and commentary. Shows locals carrying out daily activities; armed guards patrolling the border; watch-towers and concealed observation areas; propaganda billboards; ‘indoctrinated’ youths recruited as guards and frontier police; the ‘forcible’ removal of families from their ancestral homes into detention centres; and endless footage of barbed wire and uniformed personnel.
